p.s: In my opinion, Sir David's speech consisted of suitable references and an interesting way of presenting it, which all added to the impact the speech might has made on the audience attending as well as a broader public audience.

While I'm not sure if the illustration with stunning, cinematic pictures in the background was necessary or a bit over the top, I am certain that it has left an impact on a visual level on especially the broader public watching.

By choosing to stick with easy references, such as the new industrial revolution and leaving out statistics completely, the speech is easily understandable and suitable for audience without the scientific knowledge about climate change.
Attenborough's non-political approach and humane plead for action, leaves an impact on all audiences.
Considering his position I also believe it to be very appropriate, because it makes it clear that it's on the politicians to act.
The fact that he urges them to act, without attacking them or sharply criticizing them, makes it easier for him to reach them.
Looking back at 2016, Leonardo DiCaprio's speech functions in a similar way it was generally well received, so I do not think that Sir David can go any wrong with his approach.
